name: acetic anhydride production, acetaldehyde oxidation | acetic acid, without water, in 98% solution state | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/377/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of acetic anhydride, with acetic acid as byproduct, through the oxidation of acetaldehyde.;Today, acetic anhydride is made mostly by either the ketene process or the oxidation of acetaldehyde (Sutter, 2007). Production by another process, the carbonylation of methyl acetate (Halcon process), was begun in 1983. In Western Europe, 77 % of acetic anhydride is made by the ketene process and 23 % by the oxidation of acetaldehyde. Since production by the Halcon process began at the Tennessee-Eastman plant, 25 % of acetic anhydride in the United States has been made by this process and 75 % by the ketene process.;Acetic anhydride is used chiefly as an acetylating and dehydrating agent; it is used on a large scale for the acetylation of cellulose (Sutter, 2007). Other areas of application for acetic anhydride are the production of poly(methylacrylimide) hard foam, acetylated plastic auxiliaries, explosives, particularly hexogen production, the production of certain types of brake fluids, the production of auxiliaries for drilling fluids, the detergent industry, for the production of cold – bleaching activators, the dyeing industry, in the preparation of organic intermediates, in the production of pharmaceuticals, in the food industry, flavors and fragrances, and herbicides such as metolachlor (Dual) and alachlor (Lasso).;In this dataset, the raw material inputs, and process-specific material exchanges, are modelled with a generic stoichiometry-based tool, using literature or estimated yields. The emissions are modelled with a default value, which is estimated based on losses, unreacted chemicals, among others. At the same time, the energy consumption is based on data from literature sources. Finally, the auxiliary (i.e., cooling water and infrastructure) exchanges are modelled with a default value based on industry data from literature sources. For more information on the calculations refer to the sampling procedure.;References:;Sutter, J. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Petrochemical Solvents. ecoinvent report No. 22. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, 2007.;Kirk, Raymond E., Donald F. Othmer, and Charles A. Mann. "Encyclopedia of Chemical Technology." 2004.;Held, H., Rengstl, A., Mayer, D.: Acetic anhydride and mixed fatty acid anhydrides. In: "Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial." 2004

The activity starts when the raw materials enter the process.

The activity ends with acetic anhydride being ready for further transformation or transportation at the production site gate. Materials entering the process are included as well as energy uses, infrastructure and emissions.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The time period spans from the earliest year from which at least one of the input values was obtained until 2022, but overall form the most realistic picture of the production. Besides, the activity is partly generated, in terms of material inputs and outputs, based on a generic stoichiometry-based model, using literature or estimated yields, which does not expect to change over time.;The source of information for the heat and electricity inputs is literature data (from 1989) for the specific technology. Finally, the main source of information for the values for water (process and cooling), nitrogen, chemical factory is industry data from the GENDORF Chemical Park. The values are a 5-year average of data from 2015 to 2019 published by the GENDORF Chemical Park, which is based in Germany and produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances in the years 2015-2019. The end time period is therefore set based on the years from Gendorf reference.;For more information on the calculations refer to the sampling procedure and in the comments of the exchanges.;References:;Hischier, R. (2005) Establishing Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals Based on Differing Data Availability (9 pp). The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, Volume 10, Issue 1, pp 59-67. 10.1065/lca2004.10.181.7;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit;Chauvel, Alain, Gilles Lefebvre, and L. Castex in "Petrochemical processes. Technical and economical characteristics Vol. 2." (1989);G. Margaret Wells, “Handbook of Petrochemicals and Processes”, 2nd edition, Ashgate, 1999
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is modelled for Europe. The main material inputs and outputs of this activity are generated with on a generic stoichiometry-based model, using literature or estimated yields. Furthermore, the source of information for the heat and electricity inputs is literature data for the specific technology. Finally, the main source of information for the values for water (process and cooling), nitrogen, chemical factory is industry data from the GENDORF Chemical Park, which is based in Germany and produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances in the years 2015-2019. For more information on the calculations refer to the sampling procedure.;The dataset could also be considered as not geography-specific, and thus, valid for a broader geographical coverage.;References:;Hischier, R. (2005) Establishing Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals Based on Differing Data Availability (9 pp). The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, Volume 10, Issue 1, pp 59-67. 10.1065/lca2004.10.181.7;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit;Chauvel, Alain, Gilles Lefebvre, and L. Castex in "Petrochemical processes. Technical and economical characteristics Vol. 2." (1989)
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: In this dataset acetic anhydride is obtained directly by liquid-phase oxidation of acetaldehyde. At first, peracetic acid is formed from oxygen and acetaldehyde. Subsequently, the peracetic acid reacts under suitable conditions with a second molecule of acetaldehyde to form acetic anhydride and water:;CH3CHO + O2 → CH3CO3H;CH3CHO + CH3CO3H → C4H6O3 + H2O;An additional reaction takes place, where the intermediate product (peracetic acid) decomposes by water to produce acetic acid and hydrogen peroxide, as follows:;CH3CO3H + H2O ⇌ H2O2 + CH3CO2H;Therefore, acetic acid is co-produced along with the acetic anhydride product.;The operating conditions of this production process are as follows: pressure at 2-3 bar and temperatures kept between 40-60°C. Besides, at higher temperatures acetic anhydride decomposes rapidly. The strong exothermicity of the reaction creates the need for efficient cooling. At the same time, ethyl acetate is used as diluent (regenerated and recycled), and is mixed with acetaldehyde in the ratio of 2:1. Several other diluents can be used, such as methylene chloride, diisopropyl ether, cyclohexane, alkyl benzoates, and alkyl phthalates. Notably, the catalytic system (which could be regenerated) along with the rapid removal of generated water is crucial in this process. Some suitable catalysts are the following (i) mixtures of manganese acetate and copper acetate, (ii) of cobalt acetate and nickel acetate, (iii) and of cobalt and copper salts of higher fatty acids. In general, the acetaldehyde and diluent mixture is introduced with the addition of 0.05 to 0.1 % cobalt acetate and copper acetate at 40 °C; the ratio of Co:Cu is 1:2.;The reactor outlet is fed into a water-cooled condenser, and subsequently, the dehydrated mixture is sent to a distillation collumn system where acetic anydrite is recovered and unreacted acetaldehyde is reclaimed and recycled to the reactor. Finally, the off-gases are flared.;In this dataset, a yield of 95% was assumed for the production of (i) the peracetic acid and (ii) the acetic anhydride. For the decomposition of the anhydride to acetic acid a yield of 100% was assumed.;References:;Held, H., Rengstl, A., Mayer, D.: Acetic anhydride and mixed fatty acid anhy-drides. In: Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial;Sutter, J. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Petrochemical Solvents. ecoinvent report No. 22. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, 2007.;G. Margaret Wells, “Handbook of Petrochemicals and Processes”, 2nd edition, Ashgate, 1999
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Literature data and stoichiometric calculation. This inventory is partially based on a generic model of the production of chemicals. The data generated by this model have been improved with compound-specific data when available. The model of the production of chemicals is using specific industry or literature data wherever possible and more generic data on chemical production processes to fill compound-specific data gaps when necessary. The basic principles of the model have been published in literature (Hischier, 2005). The model has been updated and extended with newly available data from the chemical industry. In the model, unreacted fractions are treated in a waste treatment process, and emissions reported are after a waste treatment process that is included in the scope of this dataset. For volatile reactants, a small level of evaporation is assumed. Solvents and catalysts are mostly recycled in closed-loop systems within the scope of the dataset and reported flows are for losses from this system. The source of information for the heat and electricity inputs is literature data (from 1989) for the specific technology. Finally, the main source of information for the values for water (process and cooling), nitrogen, and chemical factory is industry data from the GENDORF Chemical Park. The values are a 5-year average of data from 2015 to 2019 published by the GENDORF Chemical Park, which is based in Germany and produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances in the years 2015-2019. For more information refer to the comments of the exchanges. References: Hischier, R. (2005) Establishing Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals Based on Differing Data Availability (9 pp). The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, Volume 10, Issue 1, pp 59-67. 10.1065/lca2004.10.181.7 Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chauvel, Alain, Gilles Lefebvre, and L. Castex in "Petrochemical processes. Technical and economical characteristics Vol. 2." (1989)

exchanges.description:
Value reported by Chauvel, Alain, Gilles Lefebvre, and L. Castex in "Petrochemical processes. Technical and economical characteristics Vol. 2." (1989).
According to Chauvel et al (1989), 1.1 kg of acetaldehyde is oxidized yielding 1 kg of acetic anhydrite and 0.2 kg of acetic acid. 

At the same time, this value is estimated, based on the input amount, the expected output, and the reaction scheme. Calculated value based on stoichiometric calculations and literature data. For more information on the calculations refer to the sampling procedure.

exchanges.description:
This value is estimated based on the cooling requirements reported by Chauvel, Alain, Gilles Lefebvre, and L. Castex in "Petrochemical processes. Technical and economical characteristics Vol. 2." (1989). The value of cooling water input for the latter process is 0.3 m3 per kg. 

At the same time, the latter amount was split between the following sources (1) "Water, cooling, unspecified natural origin", (2) "Water, river", and (3) "Water, well. in ground"

This value is estimated based on the cooling requirements reported by Chauvel, Alain, Gilles Lefebvre, and L. Castex in "Petrochemical processes. Technical and economical characteristics Vol. 2." (1989). The value of cooling water input for the latter process is 0.3 m3 per kg. 

At the same time, the latter amount was split between the following sources (1) "Water, cooling, unspecified natural origin", (2) "Water, river", and (3) "Water, well. in ground"

Calculated losses, based on the boiling point of a chemical, to water or to air. In addition, unreacted chemicals are assumed to go to wastewater treatment, which has a conversion rate in biological treatment of 95% of carbon into carbon dioxide. The remaining 5% are released as emissions to water.

As reported in the literature provide below, the acetaldehyde and diluent mixture (with a ratio of 1:2) is introduced in the reactor with the addition of 0.05 to 0.1 % cobalt acetate and copper acetate at 40 °C; the ratio of Co:Cu is 1:2. This, according to the input of acetaldehyde, leads to 0.00165 kg of catalyst input per kg of acetic anhydrite produced.

In Wells (1999) a value of 0.001 kg of catalyst is reported per kg of acetic anhydride produced (for an input of 1.2 kg of acetaldehyde and 2.4 kg of diluent). At the same time, it is also stated that the latter amount can be lower if the catalyst is regenerated and the diluent recycled. 

We, here, use the most conservative value of 0.00165 kg of catalytic system, with a Co:Cu ratio of 1:2.

References:
G. Margaret Wells, “Handbook of Petrochemicals and Processes”, 2nd edition, Ashgate, 1999
Held, H., Rengstl, A., Mayer, D.: Acetic anhydride and mixed fatty acid anhydrides. In: "Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial." 2004

Calculated losses, based on the boiling point of a chemical, to water or to air. In addition, unreacted chemicals are assumed to go to wastewater treatment, which has a conversion rate in biological treatment of 95% of carbon into carbon dioxide. The remaining 5% are released as emissions to water.
Calculated value. The BOD, COD, TOC and BOD5 are calculated based on the amount and type of emissions released to water in the same activity.

Proxy for copper acetate.
As reported in the literature provide below, the acetaldehyde and diluent mixture (with a ratio of 1:2) is introduced in the reactor with the addition of 0.05 to 0.1 % cobalt acetate and copper acetate at 40 °C; the ratio of Co:Cu is 1:2. This, according to the input of acetaldehyde, leads to 0.00165 kg of catalyst input per kg of acetic anhydrite produced.

In Wells (1999) a value of 0.001 kg of catalyst is reported per kg of acetic anhydride produced (for an input of 1.2 kg of acetaldehyde and 2.4 kg of diluent). At the same time, it is also stated that the latter amount can be lower if the catalyst is regenerated and the diluent recycled. 

We, here, use the most conservative value of 0.00165 kg of catalytic system, with a Co:Cu ratio of 1:2.

References:
G. Margaret Wells, “Handbook of Petrochemicals and Processes”, 2nd edition, Ashgate, 1999
Held, H., Rengstl, A., Mayer, D.: Acetic anhydride and mixed fatty acid anhydrides. In: "Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial." 2004

Calculated value. The BOD, COD, TOC and BOD5 are calculated based on the amount and type of emissions released to water in the same activity.

As reported in the literature provide below, the diluent amount compared to acetaldehyde, when the mixture enters the reactor, has a ratio of 2:1. This exchange represents the make-up amount needed after recovering the diluent agen, assuming a recovery of 99%. For more information, see the mathematical relation.

References:
G. Margaret Wells, “Handbook of Petrochemicals and Processes”, 2nd edition, Ashgate, 1999
Held, H., Rengstl, A., Mayer, D.: Acetic anhydride and mixed fatty acid anhydrides. In: "Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial." 2004

exchanges.description:
This value is estimated based on the cooling requirements reported by Chauvel, Alain, Gilles Lefebvre, and L. Castex in "Petrochemical processes. Technical and economical characteristics Vol. 2." (1989). The value of cooling water input for the latter process is 0.3 m3 per kg. 

At the same time, the latter amount was split between the following sources (1) "Water, cooling, unspecified natural origin", (2) "Water, river", and (3) "Water, well. in ground"

Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical. References: Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH. Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.
